pros: Very welcoming Everyone is friendly and will always help if you need it Positive workplace Great work ethic
cons: Cannot think of anything negative

pros: - I got to develop many valuable skills that will look good on my CV. - I was able to spend most of my gap year between doing something productive. - Other VMs were also really friendly. - Friday training days were fun with some great challenges and workshops.
cons: - Lack of partner schools in my site meant that travelling to and from the school was long (1hr-1hr30 depending on traffic). - The day is a bit too intense, with little to no breaks. This can also lead to burnout. - Can start to negatively impact mental and physical health as a result of burnout. - Class teachers can be hostile towards you and the City Year staff don't always do much to support you when this happens. - Volunteers often feel like we don't get enough of a voice in this programme and under appreciated. - Work/Life balance was difficult because of the long hours, intensive day + long travel. - Unclear communication between school staff of what is expected from CY.

pros: Staff are friendly and easy to get along with
cons: Unfair when it comes to pay for middle managers and those who have been in the organisation for long

pros: Nice team to work with
cons: Not a lot of upward mobility

pros: first hand experience in a school
cons: lack of support and guidance

pros: Its a well intentioned programme that gives an opportunity for people to work for a charity and make an impact. There is lots of opportunity for them to make it fun and unique.
cons: High work load and constant changes being made which can be hard to keep up with or impliment.

pros: Good experience and as can now handle anything
cons: Overworked , drained, unfair treatment

review_title: Inspiring charity, supportive and diverse team
pros:
- The volunteers really make the organisation what it is, it's inspiring to work with young adults who give a year supporting disadvantaged children.
- The charity thinks outside the box and is at the forefront of full-time volunteering in the UK. 
- Very supportive team members who are passionate about the cause.
- Strong commitment to diversity and inclusion and volunteers and staff are very diverse, making it an exciting and progressive organisation to work at in many ways.
cons:
- The framing of volunteers as beneficiaries rather than an asset confuses the message of what the charity does, the volunteers give a lot more than they get back (40+ hour weeks for stipend of £100 per week).
- At the time the organisation was going through a period of transition, no Chief Exec and some senior managers comfortable in their roles were not providing the leadership the organisation needed, causing instability and redundancies. 
- Trustees are not representative of the volunteers or communities they serve.

review_title: Great experience if you make the most out of it
pros: If you want to challenge yourself or improve your leadership skills in a supportive environment, City Year will help you discover your natural strengths and there is plenty of opportunity to grow.
cons:
No formal qualifications for completing the year
Felt like the most caring people in the world that want to help were the most-exploited 
Pay is low for the amount of work that is required (7.30am-5pm full time for £90 a week is very weak even for a charity)

pros: Nothing really it’s good work experience and the job is easy to get they’ll hire just about anyone
cons: Bad pay, bad hours, overworked

pros:
Caring 
Good teamwork

cons:
Low wages for the role 
Management didn’t have a plan for recruiting schools

pros: If you want to work in education, it’s good experience
cons:

review_title: Full time work as a volunteer
pros: Gained experience in primary or secondary schools
cons: No wage even though it's full time hours, receive a living allowance

pros:
Develop all staff 
Meaningful Work
cons: Low wage - but understandable

pros:
I would rate my current experience a 3.
- My team (Wouldn't be half as enjoyable without them)
- You will gain valuable skills and get to meet some lovely kids.
- Most school staff are nice.
cons:
- Low pay ( Expected as it as a voluntary role )
- Heavy workload makes it hard to juggle other commitments (Uni). This is especially harder during a pandemic. 
- Feeling like a spare part in certain aspects of the role and not fitting in.

review_title: Good for experience otherwise too much work for what its worth
pros: Working in a team so there are opportunities to develop team working skills which are valuable in future positions. Very friendly superiors for the most part that are easy to talk to and ask for advice
cons: They were unable to place me in the city where I live so there was an hour commute there and back and the extra pay for travel did not cover these expenses. A very physically and emotionally draining job for little pay.

pros: Experience can for cv is beneficial for people
cons: Not much pay for people, no point

pros: Great team and good experience for the future
cons:
Pay does not reflect the hours and effort put in
Manager controls everything we do, to the point where the whole team feels so drained, mentally and physically.

pros:
Mentorship from external partners like Credit Suisse, National Grid, JBC
Face to Face leadership training on Fridays are fun and thorough
Get to meet some incredibly passionate people
cons:
Pay is very minimal and often feel very undervalued working in a school (expected to work full time hours for £18 a day)
You are an unsalaried teaching assistant with more responsibilities
No certified qualifications on completion

pros: Help to Improve lots of skills like communication and self-confidence
cons: Its a full time job but still very low pay scale

pros:
Great Experience 
Hands on youth work
Professional development opportunities

job_title: Volunteer Learning Mentor in Birmingham, England
pros: It is a good organisation
cons: Not a lot of schools to work with

pros: Nice atmosphere between mentors and city year.
cons: Your experience is really dependant on the school environment to which you are sent.

pros:
The staff at City Year are amazing and fun to work with

The work is varied which always keeps me on my toes, but also enables me to build experience in different areas

The location is easy to commute to 

City Year's ethos is all about young people helping disadvantaged children, and I can see first hand how valuable young people are, and how committed they can be!
cons:
Pay could be a little higher

At times there seems to be delayed communication which means that there isn't enough time to digest the situation and to act accordingly

pros:
Building relationships with students
Building relationships with team members
Work experience (but any type of job gives you work experience)
cons:
Terrible work life balanced
For a volunteer role, it is way too demanding and draining
Training isn't all that relevant, more of a youth club when you could be using that time doing something else (e.g. a paid part time job etc)
Awful work hours considering the pay
Not standardised, different schools may work for shorter hours
Can be placed very far from home
Not enjoyable especially if you have in plans of having a career in education

review_title: CYUK: a fantastic organisation to work for
job_title: Human Resources Officer in Islington, England
pros:
- The chance to develop and take on new projects
- Intelligent and diligent management, open to new ideas and feedback 
- Flexible and homeworking
- A challenging and supportive environment
- Values driven
- Distinct culture
- A venerable mission to work towards (making real progress changing the status of full-time social action)
cons: - The normal challenges of working in the third sector, however, it stands well in the sector relatively to my other experiences.

job_title: Volunteer Learning Mentor in London, England
pros:
- fulfilling work, working with disadvantaged students can be very rewarding 
- freedom to plan and run your own initiatives
cons:
- low expenses paid, the amount has not changed in 10 years despite inflation rises 
- lack of day to day structure 
- less leadership development opportunities than was informed of
- culture is very americanised 
- working in a school that does not know or fully understand your role

pros:
Gained skills as a youth mentor, which has proven useful in any job you move on to after CY. You also get to meet and work with individuals from very different backgrounds. The skills you develop actively resolving challenges as a result of this melting pot is extremely useful as you move through life and deal with challenging people and situations in your professional and personal life.

They have a life after city year scheme where you receive emails about job vacancies in the charity sector that is applicable to the skills you gain as a corps member.
cons:
Despite being a charity that is based on the philosophy " Be the change you want to see in the world", the organisation's management do not set by example whatsoever. Took advantage of a group of vulnerable young people with little job prospects in an economic recession or young people who genuinely help disadvantaged youth. Expected us to carry out tasks in the cold at the crack of dawn (e.g. Litter picking, rallies, etc).

Made false promises of internships and prospects of corporate connections through the organisation, which was untrue. 

Very political. They don't value the hardworkers who make the most positive impact on the team, but those who spend most of their time with management in the offices. out of sight, out of mind.

Worked extremely long hours for little return career-wise in the grand scheme of things. If you want to go into teaching or want to work with children just go directly to schools in your area because City Year comes with the unnecessary extras.

pros:
- A surplus of professional development and networking opportunities
- Great impact being made
- Brilliant culture and values
- Room for growth within the organisation
- Expanding across the UK, so opportunity to relocate to another city
- Really great social aspects e.g. team socials, staff parties, talent shows
cons: - Very long hours and a lot expected of us, without satisfactory benefits

job_title: Volunteer Learning Mentor in London, England
pros: Made some great friendships with team members; positive relationships with the children that I worked with; found out about good career opportunities.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

pros:
- A lot of culture!
- Professional development is instilled from the very beginning
- Great experience if you want to work in a school
cons: Very long hours for volunteers.
